individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Benedick didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I noted her not but I looked on her

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Is she not a modest young lady

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Do you question me as an honest man should do for my simple true judgment Or would you have me speak after my custom as being a professed tyrant to their sex

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: No I pray thee speak in sober judgment

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Why i’ faith methinks she’s too low for a high praise too brown for a fair praise and too little for a great praise Only this commendation I can afford her that were she other than she is she were unhandsome and being no other but as she is I do not like her

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Thou thinkest I am in sport I pray thee tell me truly how thou lik’st her

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Would you buy her that you enquire after her

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Can the world buy such a jewel

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Yea and a case to put it into But speak you this with a sad brow Or do you play the flouting jack to tell us Cupid is a good hare-finder and Vulcan a rare carpenter Come in what key shall a man take you to go in the song

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I looked on

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I can see yet without spectacles and I see no such matter There’s her cousin an she were not possessed with a fury exceeds her as much in beauty as the first of May doth the last of December But I hope you have no intent to turn husband have you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I would scarce trust myself though I had sworn the contrary if Hero would be my wife

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Is ’t come to this In faith hath not the world one man but he will wear his cap with suspicion Shall I never see a bachelor of threescore again Go to i’ faith an thou wilt needs thrust thy neck into a yoke wear the print of it and sigh away Sundays Look Don Pedro is returned to seek you

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonPedro_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: What secret hath held you here that you followed not to Leonato’s

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: That a woman conceived me I thank her that she brought me up I likewise give her most humble thanks But that I will have a recheat winded in my forehead or hang my bugle in an invisible baldrick all women shall pardon me Because I will not do them the wrong to mistrust any I will do myself the right to trust none And the fine is for the which I may go the finer I will live a bachelor

individual_exchanges.text: My liege your Highness now may do me good

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonPedro_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: My love is thine to teach Teach it but how And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn Any hard lesson that may do thee good

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Hath Leonato any son my lord

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonPedro_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: No child but Hero she’s his only heir Dost thou affect her Claudio

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: O my lord When you went onward on this ended action I looked upon her with a soldier’s eye That liked but had a rougher task in hand Than to drive liking to the name of love But now I am returned and that war thoughts Have left their places vacant in their rooms Come thronging soft and delicate desires All prompting me how fair young Hero is Saying I liked her ere I went to wars

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonPedro_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Thou wilt be like a lover presently And tire the hearer with a book of words If thou dost love fair Hero cherish it And I will break with her and with her father And thou shalt have her Was ’t not to this end That thou began’st to twist so fine a story

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: How sweetly you do minister to love That know love’s grief by his complexion But lest my liking might too sudden seem I would have salved it with a longer treatise

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonPedro_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: What need the bridge much broader than the flood The fairest grant is the necessity Look what will serve is fit ’Tis once thou lovest And I will fit thee with the remedy I know we shall have reveling tonight I will assume thy part in some disguise And tell fair Hero I am Claudio And in her bosom I’ll unclasp my heart And take her hearing prisoner with the force And strong encounter of my amorous tale Then after to her father will I break And the conclusion is she shall be thine In practice let us put it presently

individual_exchanges.speaker: Leonato_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: How now brother where is my cousin your son Hath he provided this music

individual_exchanges.speaker: LeonatosBrother_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: He is very busy about it But brother I can tell you strange news that you yet dreamt not of

individual_exchanges.speaker: Leonato_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Are they good

individual_exchanges.speaker: LeonatosBrother_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: As the events stamps them but they have a good cover they show well outward The Prince and Count Claudio walking in a thick-pleached alley in mine orchard were thus much overheard by a man of mine the Prince discovered to Claudio that he loved my niece your daughter and meant to acknowledge it this night in a dance and if he found her accordant he meant to take the present time by the top and instantly break with you of it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Leonato_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this

individual_exchanges.speaker: LeonatosBrother_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: A good sharp fellow I will send for him and question him yourself

individual_exchanges.speaker: Leonato_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: No no we will hold it as a dream till it appear itself But I will acquaint my daughter withal that she may be the better prepared for an answer if peradventure this be true Go you and tell her of it Enter Antonio’s son with a Musician and Attendants Cousins you know what you have to do O I cry you mercy friend Go you with me and I will use your skill Good cousin have a care this busy time

individual_exchanges.speaker: Conrade_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: What the goodyear my lord why are you thus out of measure sad

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonJohn_Ado

individual_exchanges.speaker: Conrade_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: You should hear reason

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonJohn_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: And when I have heard it what blessing brings it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Conrade_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: If not a present remedy at least a patient sufferance

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonJohn_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I wonder that thou being as thou sayst thou art born under Saturn goest about to apply a moral medicine to a mortifying mischief I cannot hide what I am I must be sad when I have cause and smile at no man’s jests eat when I have stomach and wait for no man’s leisure sleep when I am drowsy and tend on no man’s business laugh when I am merry and claw no man in his humor

individual_exchanges.speaker: Conrade_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Yea but you must not make the full show of this till you may do it without controlment You have of late stood out against your brother and he hath ta’en you newly into his grace where it is impossible you should take true root but by the fair weather that you make yourself It is needful that you frame the season for your own harvest

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonJohn_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in his grace and it better fits my blood to be disdained of all than to fashion a carriage to rob love from any In this though I cannot be said to be a flattering honest man it must not be denied but I am a plain-dealing villain I am trusted with a muzzle and enfranchised with a clog therefore I have decreed not to sing in my cage If I had my mouth I would bite if I had my liberty I would do my liking In the meantime let me be that I am and seek not to alter me

individual_exchanges.speaker: Conrade_Ado

individual_exchanges.text: No but to the gate and there will the devil meet me like an old cuckold with horns on his head and say Get you to heaven Beatrice get you to heaven here’s no place for you maids So deliver I up my apes and away to Saint Peter for the heavens he shows me where the bachelors sit and there live we as merry as the day is long

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: The fault will be in the music cousin if you be not wooed in good time If the Prince be too important tell him there is measure in everything and so dance out the answer For hear me Hero wooing wedding and repenting is as a Scotch jig a measure and a cinquepace The first suit is hot and hasty like a Scotch jig and full as fantastical the wedding mannerly modest as a measure full of state and ancientry and then comes repentance and with his bad legs falls into the cinquepace faster and faster till he sink into his grave

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Why he is the Prince’s jester a very dull fool only his gift is in devising impossible slanders None but libertines delight in him and the commendation is not in his wit but in his villainy for he both pleases men and angers them and then they laugh at him and beat him I am sure he is in the fleet I would he had boarded me

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Thus answer I in name of Benedick But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio ’Tis certain so The Prince woos for himself Friendship is constant in all other things Save in the office and affairs of love Therefore all hearts in love use their own tongues Let every eye negotiate for itself And trust no agent for beauty is a witch Against whose charms faith melteth into blood This is an accident of hourly proof Which I mistrusted not Farewell therefore Hero

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Count Claudio

individual_exchanges.text: Whither

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Even to the next willow about your own business county What fashion will you wear the garland of About your neck like an usurer’s chain Or under your arm like a lieutenant’s scarf You must wear it one way for the Prince hath got your Hero

individual_exchanges.text: I wish him joy of her

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado

individual_exchanges.text: Ho now you strike like the blind man ’Twas the boy that stole your meat and you’ll beat the post

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Alas poor hurt fowl now will he creep into sedges But that my Lady Beatrice should know me and not know me The Prince’s fool Ha it may be I go under that title because I am merry Yea but so I am apt to do myself wrong I am not so reputed It is the base though bitter disposition of Beatrice that puts the world into her person and so gives me out Well I’ll be revenged as I may

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: O she misused me past the endurance of a block An oak but with one green leaf on it would have answered her My very visor began to assume life and scold with her She told me not thinking I had been myself that I was the Prince’s jester that I was duller than a great thaw huddling jest upon jest with such impossible conveyance upon me that I stood like a man at a mark with a whole army shooting at me She speaks poniards and every word stabs If her breath were as terrible as her terminations there were no living near her she would infect to the North Star I would not marry her though she were endowed with all that Adam had left him before he transgressed She would have made Hercules have turned spit yea and have cleft his club to make the fire too Come talk not of her You shall find her the infernal Ate in good apparel I would to God some scholar would conjure her for certainly while she is here a man may live as quiet in hell as in a sanctuary and people sin upon purpose because they would go thither So indeed all disquiet horror and perturbation follows her

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonPedro_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: And Benedick is not the unhopefullest husband that I know Thus far can I praise him he is of a noble strain of approved valor and confirmed honesty I will teach you how to humor your cousin that she shall fall in love with Benedick And I with your two helps will so practice on Benedick that in despite of his quick wit and his queasy stomach he shall fall in love with Beatrice If we can do this Cupid is no longer an archer his glory shall be ours for we are the only love gods Go in with me and I will tell you my drift

individual_exchanges.speaker: Borachio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Yea my lord but I can cross it

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonJohn_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Any bar any cross any impediment will be med’cinable to me I am sick in displeasure to him and whatsoever comes athwart his affection ranges evenly with mine How canst thou cross this marriage

individual_exchanges.speaker: Borachio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Not honestly my lord but so covertly that no dishonesty shall appear in me

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonJohn_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Show me briefly how

individual_exchanges.speaker: Borachio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I think I told your Lordship a year since how much I am in the favor of Margaret the waiting gentlewoman to Hero

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonJohn_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I remember

individual_exchanges.speaker: Borachio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I can at any unseasonable instant of the night appoint her to look out at her lady’s chamber window

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonJohn_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: What life is in that to be the death of this marriage

individual_exchanges.speaker: Borachio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: The poison of that lies in you to temper Go you to the Prince your brother spare not to tell him that he hath wronged his honor in marrying the renowned Claudio whose estimation do you mightily hold up to a contaminated stale such a one as Hero

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonJohn_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: What proof shall I make of that

individual_exchanges.speaker: Borachio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Proof enough to misuse the Prince to vex Claudio to undo Hero and kill Leonato Look you for any other issue

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonJohn_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Only to despite them I will endeavor anything

individual_exchanges.speaker: Borachio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Go then find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and the Count Claudio alone Tell them that you know that Hero loves me intend a kind of zeal both to the Prince and Claudio as in love of your brother’s honor who hath made this match and his friend’s reputation who is thus like to be cozened with the semblance of a maid that you have discovered thus They will scarcely believe this without trial Offer them instances which shall bear no less likelihood than to see me at her chamber window hear me call Margaret Hero hear Margaret term me Claudio and bring them to see this the very night before the intended wedding for in the meantime I will so fashion the matter that Hero shall be absent and there shall appear such seeming truth of Hero’s disloyalty that jealousy shall be called assurance and all the preparation overthrown

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonJohn_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Grow this to what adverse issue it can I will put it in practice Be cunning in the working this and thy fee is a thousand ducats

individual_exchanges.speaker: Borachio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Be you constant in the accusation and my cunning shall not shame me

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonJohn_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I will presently go learn their day of marriage

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I know that but I would have thee hence and here again Boy exits I do much wonder that one man seeing how much another man is a fool when he dedicates his behaviors to love will after he hath laughed at such shallow follies in others become the argument of his own scorn by falling in love and such a man is Claudio I have known when there was no music with him but the drum and the fife and now had he rather hear the tabor and the pipe I have known when he would have walked ten mile afoot to see a good armor and now will he lie ten nights awake carving the fashion of a new doublet He was wont to speak plain and to the purpose like an honest man and a soldier and now is he turned orthography his words are a very fantastical banquet just so many strange dishes May I be so converted and see with these eyes I cannot tell I think not I will not be sworn but love may transform me to an oyster but I’ll take my oath on it till he have made an oyster of me he shall never make me such a fool One woman is fair yet I am well another is wise yet I am well another virtuous yet I am well but till all graces be in one woman one woman shall not come in my grace Rich she shall be that’s certain wise or I’ll none virtuous or I’ll never cheapen her fair or I’ll never look on her mild or come not near me noble or not I for an angel of good discourse an excellent musician and her hair shall be of what color it please God Ha The Prince and Monsieur Love I will hide me in the arbor

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: This can be no trick The conference was sadly borne they have the truth of this from Hero they seem to pity the lady It seems her affections have their full bent Love me Why it must be requited I hear how I am censured They say I will bear myself proudly if I perceive the love come from her They say too that she will rather die than give any sign of affection I did never think to marry I must not seem proud Happy are they that hear their detractions and can put them to mending They say the lady is fair ’tis a truth I can bear them witness And virtuous ’tis so I cannot reprove it And wise but for loving me by my troth it is no addition to her wit nor no great argument of her folly for I will be horribly in love with her I may chance have some odd quirks and remnants of wit broken on me because I have railed so long against marriage but doth not the appetite alter A man loves the meat in his youth that he cannot endure in his age Shall quips and sentences and these paper bullets of the brain awe a man from the career of his humor No The world must be peopled When I said I would die a bachelor I did not think I should live till I were married Here comes Beatrice By this day she’s a fair lady I do spy some marks of love in her

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Fair Beatrice I thank you for your pains

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I took no more pains for those thanks than you take pains to thank me If it had been painful I would not have come

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: You take pleasure then in the message

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Yea just so much as you may take upon a knife’s point and choke a daw withal You have no stomach signior Fare you well

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Ha Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner There’s a double meaning in that I took no more pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me That’s as much as to say Any pains that I take for you is as easy as thanks If I do not take pity of her I am a villain if I do not love her I am a Jew I will go get her picture

individual_exchanges.speaker: Hero_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Good Margaret run thee to the parlor There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice Proposing with the Prince and Claudio Whisper her ear and tell her I and Ursula Walk in the orchard and our whole discourse Is all of her Say that thou overheardst us And bid her steal into the pleachèd bower Where honeysuckles ripened by the sun Forbid the sun to enter like favorites Made proud by princes that advance their pride Against that power that bred it There will she hide her To listen our propose This is thy office Bear thee well in it and leave us alone

individual_exchanges.speaker: Hero_Ado

individual_exchanges.speaker: Hero_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Now Ursula when Beatrice doth come As we do trace this alley up and down Our talk must only be of Benedick When I do name him let it be thy part To praise him more than ever man did merit My talk to thee must be how Benedick Is sick in love with Beatrice Of this matter Is little Cupid’s crafty arrow made That only wounds by hearsay Now begin For look where Beatrice like a lapwing runs Close by the ground to hear our conference

individual_exchanges.speaker: Ursula_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: The pleasant’st angling is to see the fish Cut with her golden oars the silver stream And greedily devour the treacherous bait So angle we for Beatrice who even now Is couchèd in the woodbine coverture Fear you not my part of the dialogue

individual_exchanges.speaker: Margaret_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Moral No by my troth I have no moral meaning I meant plain holy thistle You may think perchance that I think you are in love Nay by ’r Lady I am not such a fool to think what I list nor I list not to think what I can nor indeed I cannot think if I would think my heart out of thinking that you are in love or that you will be in love or that you can be in love Yet Benedick was such another and now is he become a man He swore he would never marry and yet now in despite of his heart he eats his meat without grudging And how you may be converted I know not but methinks you look with your eyes as other women do

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Sweet prince you learn me noble thankfulness There Leonato take her back again Give not this rotten orange to your friend She’s but the sign and semblance of her honor Behold how like a maid she blushes here O what authority and show of truth Can cunning sin cover itself withal Comes not that blood as modest evidence To witness simple virtue Would you not swear All you that see her that she were a maid By these exterior shows But she is none She knows the heat of a luxurious bed Her blush is guiltiness not modesty

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Out on thee seeming I will write against it You seem to me as Dian in her orb As chaste as is the bud ere it be blown But you are more intemperate in your blood Than Venus or those pampered animals That rage in savage sensuality

individual_exchanges.speaker: DonPedro_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Why then are you no maiden Leonato I am sorry you must hear Upon mine honor Myself my brother and this grievèd count Did see her hear her at that hour last night Talk with a ruffian at her chamber window Who hath indeed most like a liberal villain Confessed the vile encounters they have had A thousand times in secret

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: O Hero what a Hero hadst thou been If half thy outward graces had been placed About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart But fare thee well most foul most fair Farewell Thou pure impiety and impious purity For thee I’ll lock up all the gates of love And on my eyelids shall conjecture hang To turn all beauty into thoughts of harm And never shall it more be gracious

individual_exchanges.speaker: Leonato_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Wherefore Why doth not every earthly thing Cry shame upon her Could she here deny The story that is printed in her blood Do not live Hero do not ope thine eyes For did I think thou wouldst not quickly die Thought I thy spirits were stronger than thy shames Myself would on the rearward of reproaches Strike at thy life Grieved I I had but one Chid I for that at frugal Nature’s frame O one too much by thee Why had I one Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes Why had I not with charitable hand Took up a beggar’s issue at my gates Who smirchèd thus and mired with infamy I might have said No part of it is mine This shame derives itself from unknown loins But mine and mine I loved and mine I praised And mine that I was proud on mine so much That I myself was to myself not mine Valuing of her why she O she is fall’n Into a pit of ink that the wide sea Hath drops too few to wash her clean again And salt too little which may season give To her foul tainted flesh

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarFrancis_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Hear me a little For I have only silent been so long And given way unto this course of fortune By noting of the lady I have marked A thousand blushing apparitions To start into her face a thousand innocent shames In angel whiteness beat away those blushes And in her eye there hath appeared a fire To burn the errors that these princes hold Against her maiden truth Call me a fool Trust not my reading nor my observations Which with experimental seal doth warrant The tenor of my book trust not my age My reverence calling nor divinity If this sweet lady lie not guiltless here Under some biting error

individual_exchanges.speaker: Hero_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: They know that do accuse me I know none If I know more of any man alive Than that which maiden modesty doth warrant Let all my sins lack mercy O my father Prove you that any man with me conversed At hours unmeet or that I yesternight Maintained the change of words with any creature Refuse me hate me torture me to death

individual_exchanges.speaker: Leonato_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I know not If they speak but truth of her These hands shall tear her If they wrong her honor The proudest of them shall well hear of it Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine Nor age so eat up my invention Nor fortune made such havoc of my means Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends But they shall find awaked in such a kind Both strength of limb and policy of mind Ability in means and choice of friends To quit me of them throughly

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarFrancis_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Pause awhile And let my counsel sway you in this case Your daughter here the princes left for dead Let her awhile be secretly kept in And publish it that she is dead indeed Maintain a mourning ostentation And on your family’s old monument Hang mournful epitaphs and do all rites That appertain unto a burial

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarFrancis_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Marry this well carried shall on her behalf Change slander to remorse That is some good But not for that dream I on this strange course But on this travail look for greater birth She dying as it must be so maintained Upon the instant that she was accused Shall be lamented pitied and excused Of every hearer For it so falls out That what we have we prize not to the worth Whiles we enjoy it but being lacked and lost Why then we rack the value then we find The virtue that possession would not show us Whiles it was ours So will it fare with Claudio When he shall hear she died upon his words Th’ idea of her life shall sweetly creep Into his study of imagination And every lovely organ of her life Shall come appareled in more precious habit More moving delicate and full of life Into the eye and prospect of his soul Than when she lived indeed Then shall he mourn If ever love had interest in his liver And wish he had not so accused her No though he thought his accusation true Let this be so and doubt not but success Will fashion the event in better shape Than I can lay it down in likelihood But if all aim but this be leveled false The supposition of the lady’s death Will quench the wonder of her infamy And if it sort not well you may conceal her As best befits her wounded reputation In some reclusive and religious life Out of all eyes tongues minds and injuries

individual_exchanges.text: Marry this well carried shall on her behalf Change slander to remorse That is some good But not for that dream I on this strange course But on this travail look for greater birth She dying as it must be so maintained Upon the instant that she was accused Shall be lamented pitied and excused Of every hearer For it so falls out That what we have we prize not to the worth Whiles we enjoy it but being lacked and lost Why then we rack the value then we find The virtue that possession would not show us Whiles it was ours So will it fare with Claudio When he shall hear she died upon his words Th’ idea of her life shall sweetly creep Into his study of imagination And every lovely organ of her life Shall come appareled in more precious habit More moving delicate and full of life Into the eye and prospect of his soul Than when she lived indeed Then shall he mourn If ever love had interest in his liver And wish he had not so accused her No though he thought his accusation true Let this be so and doubt not but success Will fashion the event in better shape Than I can lay it down in likelihood But if all aim but this be leveled false The supposition of the lady’s death Will quench the wonder of her infamy And if it sort not well you may conceal her As best befits her wounded reputation In some reclusive and religious life Out of all eyes tongues minds and injuries

individual_exchanges.text: Signior Leonato let the Friar advise you And though you know my inwardness and love Is very much unto the Prince and Claudio Yet by mine honor I will deal in this As secretly and justly as your soul Should with your body

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Lady Beatrice have you wept all this while

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Yea and I will weep a while longer

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I will not desire that

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: You have no reason I do it freely

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Ah how much might the man deserve of me that would right her

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Is there any way to show such friendship

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: A very even way but no such friend

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: May a man do it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: It is a man’s office but not yours

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I do love nothing in the world so well as you Is not that strange

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: As strange as the thing I know not It were as possible for me to say I loved nothing so well as you but believe me not and yet I lie not I confess nothing nor I deny nothing I am sorry for my cousin

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: By my sword Beatrice thou lovest me

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Do not swear and eat it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I will swear by it that you love me and I will make him eat it that says I love not you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Will you not eat your word

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: With no sauce that can be devised to it I protest I love thee

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Why then God forgive me

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: What offense sweet Beatrice

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: You have stayed me in a happy hour I was about to protest I loved you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: And do it with all thy heart

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I love you with so much of my heart that none is left to protest

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Come bid me do anything for thee

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Kill Claudio

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Ha Not for the wide world

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: You kill me to deny it Farewell

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Tarry sweet Beatrice

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I am gone though I am here There is no love in you Nay I pray you let me go

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Beatrice

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: In faith I will go

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: We’ll be friends first

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: You dare easier be friends with me than fight with mine enemy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Is Claudio thine enemy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Is he not approved in the height a villain that hath slandered scorned dishonored my kinswoman O that I were a man What bear her in hand until they come to take hands and then with public accusation uncovered slander unmitigated rancor O God that I were a man I would eat his heart in the marketplace

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Hear me Beatrice

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Talk with a man out at a window A proper saying

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Nay but Beatrice

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Sweet Hero she is wronged she is slandered she is undone

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Beat

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Princes and counties Surely a princely testimony a goodly count Count Comfect a sweet gallant surely O that I were a man for his sake Or that I had any friend would be a man for my sake But manhood is melted into curtsies valor into compliment and men are only turned into tongue and trim ones too He is now as valiant as Hercules that only tells a lie and swears it I cannot be a man with wishing therefore I will die a woman with grieving

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Tarry good Beatrice By this hand I love thee

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Use it for my love some other way than swearing by it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Think you in your soul the Count Claudio hath wronged Hero

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Yea as sure as I have a thought or a soul

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Enough I am engaged I will challenge him I will kiss your hand and so I leave you By this hand Claudio shall render me a dear account As you hear of me so think of me Go comfort your cousin I must say she is dead and so farewell

individual_exchanges.speaker: Dogberry_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Dost thou not suspect my place Dost thou not suspect my years O that he were here to write me down an ass But masters remember that I am an ass though it be not written down yet forget not that I am an ass No thou villain thou art full of piety as shall be proved upon thee by good witness I am a wise fellow and which is more an officer and which is more a householder and which is more as pretty a piece of flesh as any is in Messina and one that knows the law go to and a rich fellow enough go to and a fellow that hath had losses and one that hath two gowns and everything handsome about him Bring him away O that I had been writ down an ass

individual_exchanges.speaker: LeonatosBrother_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: If you go on thus you will kill yourself And ’tis not wisdom thus to second grief Against yourself

individual_exchanges.speaker: Leonato_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I pray thee cease thy counsel Which falls into mine ears as profitless As water in a sieve Give not me counsel Nor let no comforter delight mine ear But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine Bring me a father that so loved his child Whose joy of her is overwhelmed like mine And bid him speak of patience Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine And let it answer every strain for strain As thus for thus and such a grief for such In every lineament branch shape and form If such a one will smile and stroke his beard Bid sorrow wag cry hem when he should groan Patch grief with proverbs make misfortune drunk With candle-wasters bring him yet to me And I of him will gather patience But there is no such man For brother men Can counsel and speak comfort to that grief Which they themselves not feel but tasting it Their counsel turns to passion which before Would give preceptial med’cine to rage Fetter strong madness in a silken thread Charm ache with air and agony with words No no ’tis all men’s office to speak patience To those that wring under the load of sorrow But no man’s virtue nor sufficiency To be so moral when he shall endure The like himself Therefore give me no counsel My griefs cry louder than advertisement

individual_exchanges.speaker: LeonatosBrother_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Therein do men from children nothing differ

individual_exchanges.speaker: Leonato_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I pray thee peace I will be flesh and blood For there was never yet philosopher That could endure the toothache patiently However they have writ the style of gods And made a push at chance and sufferance

individual_exchanges.speaker: LeonatosBrother_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself Make those that do offend you suffer too

individual_exchanges.speaker: Leonato_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: There thou speak’st reason Nay I will do so My soul doth tell me Hero is belied And that shall Claudio know so shall the Prince And all of them that thus dishonor her

individual_exchanges.speaker: Borachio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Sweet prince let me go no farther to mine answer Do you hear me and let this count kill me I have deceived even your very eyes What your wisdoms could not discover these shallow fools have brought to light who in the night overheard me confessing to this man how Don John your brother incensed me to slander the Lady Hero how you were brought into the orchard and saw me court Margaret in Hero’s garments how you disgraced her when you should marry her My villainy they have upon record which I had rather seal with my death than repeat over to my shame The lady is dead upon mine and my master’s false accusation And briefly I desire nothing but the reward of a villain

individual_exchanges.speaker: Leonato_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I cannot bid you bid my daughter live That were impossible but I pray you both Possess the people in Messina here How innocent she died And if your love Can labor aught in sad invention Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb And sing it to her bones Sing it tonight Tomorrow morning come you to my house And since you could not be my son-in-law Be yet my nephew My brother hath a daughter Almost the copy of my child that’s dead And she alone is heir to both of us Give her the right you should have giv’n her cousin And so dies my revenge

individual_exchanges.speaker: Dogberry_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Moreover sir which indeed is not under white and black this plaintiff here the offender did call me ass I beseech you let it be remembered in his punishment And also the watch heard them talk of one Deformed They say he wears a key in his ear and a lock hanging by it and borrows money in God’s name the which he hath used so long and never paid that now men grow hardhearted and will lend nothing for God’s sake Pray you examine him upon that point

individual_exchanges.speaker: Dogberry_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I leave an arrant knave with your Worship which I beseech your Worship to correct yourself for the example of others God keep your Worship I wish your Worship well God restore you to health I humbly give you leave to depart and if a merry meeting may be wished God prohibit it Come neighbor

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Pray thee sweet Mistress Margaret deserve well at my hands by helping me to the speech of Beatrice

individual_exchanges.speaker: Margaret_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Will you then write me a sonnet in praise of my beauty

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: In so high a style Margaret that no man living shall come over it for in most comely truth thou deservest it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Margaret_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: To have no man come over me Why shall I always keep below stairs

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Thy wit is as quick as the greyhound’s mouth it catches

individual_exchanges.speaker: Margaret_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: And yours as blunt as the fencer’s foils which hit but hurt not

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: A most manly wit Margaret it will not hurt a woman And so I pray thee call Beatrice I give thee the bucklers

individual_exchanges.speaker: Margaret_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Give us the swords we have bucklers of our own

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: If you use them Margaret you must put in the pikes with a vice and they are dangerous weapons for maids

individual_exchanges.speaker: Margaret_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Well I will call Beatrice to you who I think hath legs

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: And therefore will come Margaret exits Sings The god of love That sits above And knows me and knows me How pitiful I deserve I mean in singing But in loving Leander the good swimmer Troilus the first employer of panders and a whole book full of these quondam carpetmongers whose names yet run smoothly in the even road of a blank verse why they were never so truly turned over and over as my poor self in love Marry I cannot show it in rhyme I have tried I can find out no rhyme to lady but baby an innocent rhyme for scorn horn a hard rhyme for school fool a babbling rhyme very ominous endings No I was not born under a rhyming planet nor I cannot woo in festival terms Enter Beatrice Sweet Beatrice wouldst thou come when I called thee

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Yea signior and depart when you bid me

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: O stay but till then

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Then is spoken Fare you well now And yet ere I go let me go with that I came which is with knowing what hath passed between you and Claudio

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Only foul words and thereupon I will kiss thee

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Foul words is but foul wind and foul wind is but foul breath and foul breath is noisome Therefore I will depart unkissed

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Thou hast frighted the word out of his right sense so forcible is thy wit But I must tell thee plainly Claudio undergoes my challenge and either I must shortly hear from him or I will subscribe him a coward And I pray thee now tell me for which of my bad parts didst thou first fall in love with me

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: For them all together which maintained so politic a state of evil that they will not admit any good part to intermingle with them But for which of my good parts did you first suffer love for me

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Suffer love A good epithet I do suffer love indeed for I love thee against my will

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: In spite of your heart I think Alas poor heart if you spite it for my sake I will spite it for yours for I will never love that which my friend hates

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Thou and I are too wise to woo peaceably

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: It appears not in this confession There’s not one wise man among twenty that will praise himself

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: An old an old instance Beatrice that lived in the time of good neighbors If a man do not erect in this age his own tomb ere he dies he shall live no longer in monument than the bell rings and the widow weeps

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: And how long is that think you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Question why an hour in clamor and a quarter in rheum Therefore is it most expedient for the wise if Don Worm his conscience find no impediment to the contrary to be the trumpet of his own virtues as I am to myself So much for praising myself who I myself will bear witness is praiseworthy And now tell me how doth your cousin

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Very ill

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: And how do you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Beatrice_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Very ill too

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Serve God love me and mend There will I leave you too for here comes one in haste

individual_exchanges.speaker: Ursula_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: Madam you must come to your uncle Yonder’s old coil at home It is proved my Lady Hero hath been falsely accused the Prince and Claudio mightily abused and Don John is the author of all who is fled and gone Will you come presently

individual_exchanges.speaker: Ursula_Ado

individual_exchanges.text: Will you go hear this news signior

individual_exchanges.text: I will live in thy heart die in thy lap and be buried in thy eyes and moreover I will go with thee to thy uncle’s

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benedick_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I’ll tell thee what prince a college of wit-crackers cannot flout me out of my humor Dost thou think I care for a satire or an epigram No If a man will be beaten with brains he shall wear nothing handsome about him In brief since I do purpose to marry I will think nothing to any purpose that the world can say against it and therefore never flout at me for what I have said against it For man is a giddy thing and this is my conclusion For thy part Claudio I did think to have beaten thee but in that thou art like to be my kinsman live unbruised and love my cousin

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_Ado
individual_exchanges.text: I had well hoped thou wouldst have denied Beatrice that I might have cudgeled thee out of thy single life to make thee a double-dealer which out of question thou wilt be if my cousin do not look exceeding narrowly to thee

individual_exchanges.text: First of my word Therefore play music Prince thou art sad Get thee a wife get thee a wife There is no staff more reverend than one tipped with horn
